questions.text: The presence of a marked incongruence between one's experienced gender and natal gender is called _____
questions.solution:
The presence of a marked incongruence between one’s experienced gender and natal gender (gender assigned at birth) is called gender dysphoria.

Gender Dysphoria:

  • Unhappiness or a sense of inappropriateness with one’s natal sex.
  • Strong desire to get rid of the natal gender’s primary and/or secondary sex characteristics.
  • Strong desire for primary and/or secondary sex characteristics of the other gender.
  • Strong feeling that one’s feelings and reactions are more typical of the other gender.
  • Desire to be treated by others as a member of the other gender.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pacemaker of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.

In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

NOTE:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the Interstitial cells of Cajal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, a professional trumpet player, presents to the ENT clinic with a swelling on the left side of his neck that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few weeks. On examination, there is a notable gurgling sound when compressing the swelling. Due to inconclusive findings on X-ray neck, a CT scan was performed, revealing the image below. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, including the characteristic gurgling sound upon compression of the swelling (Bryce sign), along with the CT findings, is indicative of a laryngocele. A laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx, typically developing in the saccule. Patients often present with soft and compressible neck swelling, and the presence of the Bryce sign is a significant diagnostic feature.

Laryngocoele:

  • Air-filled cavity within the larynx developing in the saccule.
  • The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.
  • Bryce sign: On compressing the swelling, there is a hissing or gurgling sound.

Other options:

Option A: Zenker diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum and results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus. In patients with a large Zenker’s diverticulum, Boyce’s sign is seen (rare sign) which is characterised by a gurgling sound on palpation of the neck due to the movement of air and fluid within the diverticulum.

Option C: A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the Esophagus and Trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal oesophagal atresia and distal TEF, the proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Option D: A tonsillar cyst is due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often it is symptomless. It can be easily drained.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a deficiency of a vitamin that serves as a carrier for one carbon atom. Which of the following vitamins fulfills this role?
questions.solution:
Folic acid serves as a carrier of one carbon atom.

Tetrahydrofolate receives one-carbon fragments from donors such as serine, glycine, and histidine and transfers them to intermediates in the synthesis of amino acids, purines and pyrimidines.

Folic acid deficiency manifestations:

  • Megaloblastic anemia 
  • Homocystinemia
  • Neural tube defect(spina bifida, Anencephaly)

Note: The major point of entry for one-carbon fragments, in one-carbon metabolism, is methylenetetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: The discharge from an infected wound was cultured and the gram-stained smear of the isolated organism is given below. On performing further tests, the organism was found to be catalase and coagulase-positive. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The above micrograph showing gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters alongwith the organism being catalase and coagulase-positive is suggestive of it being Staphylococcus aureus.

The staphylococci grow in clusters because the cells divide successively in three perpendicular planes, with the daughter cells remaining attached to one another following each successive division.

Bacteria Arrangement
Staphylococcus Clusters
Streptococcus Chains
Pneumococcus Pairs/lanceolate shaped
Micrococcus Tetrads

Option A: Streptococci are catalase negative.

Options C & D: S. epidermidis and S. saprophyticus are both coagulase negative.

questions.text: At a waste treatment facility,  pharmaceutical waste was mixed with cement, lime, and water before disposal. What is this method known as?
questions.solution:
Inertization is the process of mixing biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity of the waste and to reduce the contamination of groundwater. It is most commonly done for incineration ash with high metal content.

The typical composition of the inertization mixture is:

  • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% cement
  • 15% lime
  • 5% water

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen in the image shows the presence of multiple polyps in the colon, along with an area suspicious of colorectal carcinoma. Multiple polyps in the colon of a 14-year-old boy make familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) the likely diagnosis. FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene and not due to defects in the DNA repair mechanism.

Defects in DNA mismatch repair genes result in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, MYH-associated polyposis, and some sporadic colon cancers.

Familial adenomatous polyposis, as the name suggests, is an inherited disorder presenting with numerous colorectal adenomatous polyps. It is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a regulator in the Wnt signaling pathway. At least 100 polyps are required to make a diagnosis of FAP. 

Patients are usually teenagers and multiple polyps are visible in the colon during sigmoidoscopy. It is associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations including congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmental epithelium. Colorectal adenocarcinoma occurs in almost all cases before the age of 50. 

Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations. The surgeries used are colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC), or total proctectomy and end ileostomy. The first 2 surgeries are preferred in young patients as it avoids a permanent stoma. 

Note- FAP along with brain tumors is called Turcot syndrome. FAP along with multiple osteomas, skin, and soft tissue tumors is called Gardner syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but  rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B.

This is a case of visceral leishmaniasis, and it presents with fever associated with rigor and chills. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are common. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, but in the Indian subcontinent, it is rare. 

Diagnosis is by ELISA and the indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

Medical Therapy :

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
  • If initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used.

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice.

Other drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis include: paromomycin and miltefosine.

Other options:

Option b: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

Option c: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA  and related infections.

Option d: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.text:
A case of chronic hepatitis B virus infection with high infectivity was reviewed in the ward. Which of the following serological patterns will not be seen in this condition?

HBV - Hepatitis B Virus
questions.solution:
In chronic hepatitis B virus infection with high infectivity, anti-HBs antibody is not present. Hence, it is not seen in serological patterns of this condition.

The serological pattern seen in chronic hepatitis B virus infection with high infectivity is as follows: 

  • HBsAg present
  • Anti-HBs antibody absent
  • HBeAg present
  • Anti-HBe antibody absent
  • Anti-HBc IgG present

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

  HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc

+

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

HBV infection in the remote past

Recovery - + - +/- IgG

questions.text: Identify the stage of ASOM:
questions.solution:
The image shows the stage of pre-suppuration of acute suppurative otitis media. 

During this stage, due to prolonged tubal occlusion pyogenic organisms invade the tympanic cavity. Inflammatory exudate appears in the middle ear and there is congestion of pars tensa. A Leash of blood vessels appear along the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane imparting it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the whole of the tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red.

Symptoms of this stage: There is marked earache, high degree of fever, deafness and tinnitus (seen only in adults).

Tuning fork tests show conductive type of hearing loss.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. He has a history of many comorbidities and is currently taking multiple medications. Upon further examination and diagnostic workup, the patient is diagnosed with pleural pathology, and it is suspected that one of the patient's medications might be contributing to this condition. Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause this kind of presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is associated with pleural pathology and metformin is not associated with pleural pathology.

Metformin belongs to the biguanides class of oral hypoglycemic agents. It acts by activation of AMP-dependent protein kinase (AMPK). This results in reduced hepatic glucose production.

Side effects of metformin are lactic acidosis, gastrointestinal disturbance, and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Contraindications for metformin include :

  • GFR <30 ml/min
  • Unstable CHF
  • Radiographic contrast studies
  • Hospitalized patients who cannot take anything orally
  • Acidosis

Other options:

Option B: Methysergide is a serotonin(5-HT) receptor antagonist. It was used for the treatment of migraine prophylaxis and carcinoid syndrome. But its use has been discontinued due to side effects like abdominal, pulmonary and endocardial fibrosis.

Option C: Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. It chelates copper or iron and produces superoxide ions that damage DNA. Side effects are mucocutaneous toxicity and pulmonary fibrosis.

Option D: Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic. They are used for the treatment of lower urinary tract infections (UTIs). It acts by damaging DNA and inhibiting protein synthesis in susceptible bacteria. Important side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances, liver damage and pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with features of angular stomatitis and a magenta tongue is diagnosed to have a deficiency of a certain water-soluble vitamin. Which of the following vitamins could it be?
questions.solution:
The boy is most likely to have a Vitamin B2 / Riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin is important for the metabolism of fat, carbohydrate, and protein, acting as a respiratory coenzyme and an electron donor. Enzymes that contain flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) or flavin mononucleotide (FMN) as prosthetic groups are known as flavoenzymes (e.g., succinic acid dehydrogenase, monoamine oxidase, glutathione reductase). FAD is a cofactor for methyltetrahydrofolate reductase and therefore modulates homocysteine metabolism. The vitamin also plays a role in drug and steroid metabolism, including detoxification reactions.

The clinical manifestations of riboflavin deficiency are nonspecific; patients with a Vitamin B2 / Thiamine deficiency usually present with features of a magenta-coloured tongue, angular stomatitis, seborrhea, ocular symptoms, corneal vascularization. Risk factors include alcoholism and a poor diet with a low intake of milk products. In addition, corneal vascularization, anaemia, and personality changes have been observed with riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin deficiency almost always is due to dietary deficiency. Milk and other dairy products, enriched bread, cereals, meat, fish, eggs, broccoli, and legumes are good sources of riboflavin. It is extremely sensitive to light, and milk should be stored in containers that protect against its photodegradation. Laboratory diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency can be made by determination of red blood cell or urinary riboflavin concentrations or by measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterised by a pigmented rash in skin exposed areas, bright red tongue, diarrhoea, apathy, memory loss and disorientation.

Option C: Vitamin B6/ Pyridoxine deficiency leads to symptoms such as seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion and microcytic anaemia.

Option D: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble vitamin and is not soluble in water. Its deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, retinopathy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is presbyopic. The power of his prescription glasses should be _______.
questions.solution:
The power of the prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man should be +2D.

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopia.

Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows:

Age Power
40–44 years +1D
45–49 years

+1.5D
50–54 years +2D
55–60 years +2.5D

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy sustained a wound in the forearm while playing on the ground. The wound was bleeding for some time and stopped after the formation of a blood clot. The type of homeostasis mechanism acting in this scenario is also seen in all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes the process of blood clotting which is an example of positive feedback. This is also seen in all the other conditions except pulmonary hyperventilation which is an example of negative feedback.

Pulmonary hyperventilation is a negative feedback mechanism where a stimulus (like increased CO2 in blood) leads to a response- pulmonary hyperventilation which reduces the original stimulus (blood CO2 level decreases) and brings back the system to its original state.

Positive feedback is the type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state. Negative feedback is a system where the initial stimulus triggers a response that restores the original state. 

Most mechanisms in our body follow the negative feedback mechanism which helps to maintain homeostasis. For example, an increase in gastric acids leads to a decrease in gastric secretion.

Positive feedback is seen in a few conditions where a physiological process has to propagate itself. These include:

  • Childbirth
  • Lactation
  • Blood clotting
  • LH surge
  • Action potential

Positive feedback may sometimes lead to vicious cycles, eg. shock.

questions.text: Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
Image shows trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia.

Features of Giardia trophozoite:

  • Tennis racket or heart shaped or pyriform shaped
  • Ventrally, it has a concave sucking disc, which helps in its attachment to the intestinal mucosa
  • Bilaterally symmetrical and possesses
    • 1 pair of nuclei
    • 4 pairs of flagella
    • Blepharoplast, from which the flagella arise (4 pairs)
    • 1 pair of axostyles, running along the midline
    • Two sausage­ shaped parabasal or median bodies, lying transversely posterior to the sucking disc
  • The trophozoite is motile, with a slow oscillation about its long axis, often resembling falling leaf

 

Cyst:

  • Infective stage
  • Quadrinucleate
  • Hyaline cyst wall

questions.text:
A child with impaired cognitive function was admitted for evaluation in the pediatrics ward. On examination, you find multiple types of seizures, an EEG showing slow (<3Hz) spike and wave discharges, and diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Which among the following options is a first-line drug for his condition?

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate is a first-line drug for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

Valproate is an broad spectrum antiseziure drug. It is used in:

  • Partial seizures
  • Generalised tonic-clonic seziures (GTCS)
  • Absence seziures
  • Myoclonic seziures 
  • Atonic seziures

Valproate act via multiple mechanisms like:

  • Prolonged sodium channel inactivation
  • Attenuation of calcium-mediated 'T' current 
  • Enhanced release of  inhibitory transmitter GABA due to inhibition of its degradation and increasing its synthesis from glutamic acid
  • Inhibition of excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare severe form of childhood epilepsy. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Multiple types of seizures including GTCS, atonic, myoclonic, atypical absence seizures
  • <3Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG
  • Impaired cognitive function

They are predominantly seen in early childhood between the age group of 1 to 7 years peaking at around 3 years of age. Intellectual impairment in the form of developmental delay starts usually after the occurrence of seizures.

Other options:

Option A- Zonisamide is an antiepileptic drug used as adjuvant therapy of focal seizures in adults. It can also be used as an add-on in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. 

Option B: Levetiracetam is also effective in most of the seizures present in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

Option D: Vigabatrin is also effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

questions.text: During a routine abdominal examination, a 55-year-old male patient presents with complaints of dull abdominal pain in the upper right quadrant. Upon further investigation, the physician performs an ultrasound, revealing an anomaly in the liver. Upon closer inspection, it is noted that there is an area of the liver not covered by the visceral peritoneum. In the image given below, which area corresponds to the bare area of the liver?
questions.solution:
The part of the liver marked with 'B' is the bare area of the liver, as this area marks the portion of the liver which is not covered by visceral peritoneum.

The bare area of the liver is a triangular area of the liver that is devoid of peritoneal covering. It is formed by the two layers of the coronary ligament. In this bare area, the liver is attached to the diaphragm by areolar tissue.

questions.text: Signs and symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy include
questions.solution:
Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction is the commonest symptom. This leads to mouth breathing.
  • Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, epistaxis.
  • Eustachian tube obstruction leading to bilateral serous otitis media and conductive hearing loss.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies- elongated face with dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnea- chronic cases leads to hypoxemia which leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction consequently pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducent nerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs are proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

Other options :

Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in children young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint 

Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

questions.text: Where does the digestion of disaccharides primarily occur?
questions.solution:
The digestion of disaccharides primarily occurs in the small intestine. Disaccharides, such as sucrose, lactose, and maltose, are broken down into their constituent monosaccharides in the small intestine.

The enzymes responsible for disaccharide digestion, including maltase, sucrase, isomaltase, lactase, and trehalase, are located in the enterocytes covering the intestinal microvilli brush border. As disaccharides pass through the small intestine, they come in contact with these enterocytes, where the enzymes catalyze their breakdown into monosaccharides.

Other options:

Option A: Mouth - While some starch digestion begins in the mouth through the action of salivary amylase, the digestion of disaccharides primarily occurs in the small intestine rather than the mouth.

Option B: Stomach - The stomach primarily acts as a reservoir for food and initiates the digestion of proteins through the action of gastric enzymes. Disaccharide digestion does not occur to a significant extent in the stomach.

Option D: Large intestine - The large intestine primarily functions in the absorption of water and electrolytes and the formation of feces. While some fermentation of undigested carbohydrates occurs in the large intestine, the primary site of disaccharide digestion is the small intestine.

questions.text:
Mid-term abortion is being planned for a young female. Your consultant decides to use a natural PGE2 drug as an abortifacient. Identify the drug from the following.

PGE2 - Prostaglandin E2
questions.solution:
Dinoprostone is a naturally occurring prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) preparation.

Options A: Dinoprost is a natural PGF2 alpha preparation.

Option B:  Carboprost is a 15-methyl synthetic derivative of PGF2 alpha. It is used as an abortifacient and in refractory PPH.

Option C: Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE1 analogue.

questions.text: Identify the anti-diabetic drug that  does not increases insulin release.
questions.solution:
Pioglitazone does not increase insulin release from the beta cells of the pancreas.

Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that acts by activating PPAR-gamma (nuclear receptor) which induces several genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism and thereby, decreases insulin resistance.

Nateglinide (a meglitinide) Glipizide and Glyburide (both sulfonylureas) are insulin secretagogues that act by inhibiting the ATP-sensitive K+ channels of the beta cells of the pancreas to cause insulin release.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not related to the posterior surface of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Waldeyer's fascia (presacral fascia) forms the posterior relationship of the rectum and is not related to the vagina. It lines the anterior surface of the sacrum.

Relations of the vagina:

Parts of vagina Anterior relation Posterior relation Lateral relation
Upper third Bladder Peritoneum of the rectouterine pouch

Levator ani

Transverse cervical ligament

Pubocervical ligament

Uterosacral ligament

Ureter and uterine artery (related to the lateral fornix)
Middle third Bladder Rectovaginal fascia/septum Pubovaginalis muscle
Lower third Urethra Perineal body Bulbospongiosus

questions.text: You are tasked with holding a public service announcement about the benefits of getting vaccinated to a small town of farmers. You want to deliver some statistical data to encourage vaccination. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
Pictograms are a popular method of presenting data among the laity and to those who cannot understand orthodox charts. 

Small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. These can be easily understood by laymen and have a greater impact than complex graphs or charts.

The image below is a pictogram depicting the benefits of getting vaccinated and not getting vaccinated.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent?

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infective cardiac valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. The histopathological slide shows fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species with non-pigmented, narrow, septate, hyphae with branching at 45o (acute angle).

Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic infection seen in the immunosuppressed hosts. Aspergillus has a tendency to invade blood vessels. Thus, widespread hematogenous dissemination with involvement of the heart valves and brain is common. Aspergillus form fruiting bodies and septate filaments, 5 to 10 µm thick, branching at acute angles (40 degrees). Aspergillus hyphae without the distinct fruiting body cannot be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

Rhinocerebral Aspergillus infection in immunosuppressed individuals resembles that caused by Mucormycoses (e.g., Mucor spp., Rhizopus spp.). (Option-A) Mucormycetes form broad ribbon-like non-septate pigmented hyphae of variable width (6 to 50 µm) with frequent right-angle branching, distinct from Aspergillus hyphae.

Option B: Disseminated fusariosis differs from disseminated aspergillosis as the former presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions are extremely common with fusariosis. No such history is given in the clinical stem. The organism is difficult to differentiate from Aspergillus species in tissues; thus, identification with culture is imperative.

Option C: Rhizopus shows aseptate hyphae with sporangium and sporangiophores. It is similar in appearance to that of mucormycosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the urology clinic complaining of difficulty urinating and discomfort in the perineal region. On examination, the doctor notes there is some slight swelling over the perineal membrane. Which arrow corresponds to the perineal membrane in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the given image of a median sagittal section of a male perineum, the perineal membrane is denoted by the arrow marked as C.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into:

  • A deep perineal space lying above it
  • A superficial perineal space lying below it

It has a distinct dorsal and a ventral portion, which are closely connected with Levator ani.
The dorsal portion is related to the support of the perineal body and lateral vaginal wall by its attachment to the ischiopubic ramus. The ventral portion, on the other hand, is contiguous with the structures supporting urethra.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about group discussion?

choices.text: One topic is spoken about in one discussion.
One group leader for every 3 poeple.
It usually consists of 2 to 4 people.

questions.solution:
A group discussion discusses one topic on its agenda.

Group discussion is an aggregation of people interacting in a face to face manner.

  • Exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influences a change in their attitudes.
  • It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation, giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves.
  • In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interruption of another.
  • Limitation – not everyone is open to speaking in public and possibility of diversion of topic of discussion is high when many people are involved.

questions.text:
Match the lymph nodes and the structures that drain to it:
Column A Column B
1.Para-aortic lymph nodes A.Prostate
2.External iliac lymph nodes B.Distal anal canal
3.Deep inguinal lymph nodes C.Superior Bladder
4.Internal iliac lymph nodes D.Glans penis
  E.Testis
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  • Para-aortic lymph nodes drain the testis
  • External iliac lymph nodes drain the superior bladder
  • Deep inguinal lymph nodes drain the glans penis
  • Internal iliac lymph nodes drain the prostate.

 

The para-aortic lymph nodes drain the testis. Paraaortic lymph nodes are a group of lymph nodes that lie in front of the lumbar vertebrae near the aorta. These lymph nodes receive drainage from the gastrointestinal tract and the abdominal organs. Paraaortic lymph node group is divided into three subgroups: preaortic, retroaortic, and right and left lateral aortic.

The external iliac lymph nodes drain the Superior Bladder.

The deep inguinal lymph nodes drain the glans penis. Deep inguinal lymph nodes lie medial to the femoral vein under the cribriform fascia. The uppermost node is in the groin, under the inguinal ligament, and is called Cloquet's node. The deep inguinal lymph nodes drain superiorly to the external iliac lymph nodes, then to the pelvic lymph nodes and on to the paraaortic lymph nodes.

Internal iliac lymph nodes drain the prostate. The internal iliac lymph nodes (or hypogastric) surround the internal iliac artery and its branches (the hypogastric vessels), and receive the lymphatics corresponding to the distribution of the branches of it, i.e., they receive lymphatics from all the pelvic viscera, from the deeper parts of the perineum, including the membranous and cavernous portions of the urethra, and from the buttock and back of the thigh.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of chronic sinusitis, facial pain, and nasal congestion predominantly on the right side. He reports no significant medical history except for occasional allergies. On nasal endoscopy, thick, purulent discharge is observed draining from the right middle meatus. CT imaging reveals opacification of the right maxillary sinus. He is suspected to have fungal maxillosinusitis. Which of the following fungal infections is most commonly associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Aspergillosis is the most commonly encountered fungal infection affecting the maxillary sinus. It often presents with chronic sinusitis symptoms and can lead to opacification of the sinus cavity on imaging studies. Aspergillosis and mucormycosis are the two most common fungal infections involving the maxillary sinuses.

The most common sinus affected by a fungal infection is the maxillary sinus (fungal balls), accounting for approximately 94% of the cases.

Blastomycosis, Candidiasis, and Histoplasmosis are fungal infections that can affect various parts of the body but are not typically associated with the maxillary sinus.

questions.text: A middle-aged man has been recently diagnosed with hypertension. He wants to try lifestyle changes before starting with pharmacological therapy. According to the rule of halves, where is he represented in the diagram, if A represents the whole population?
questions.solution:
According to the rule of halves, the person is represented in category C which represents people diagnosed with hypertension but not treated. This is because the patient has not yet started lifestyle management or pharmacotherapy.

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. The rule depicts the disease burden of hypertension in the community.

It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Pictorial representation of the rule of halves in hypertension is shown below:

 

Hypertension can be prevented by primary and secondary prevention strategies. Primary prevention includes non-pharmacological measures such as lifestyle changes that are taken to reduce the incidence of the disease. It includes:

  • Population strategy approach aimed to reduce the incidence of the disease at the whole population level
  • High-risk strategy approach is done to identify high-risk individuals 

Secondary prevention includes pharmacological measures such as the usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. It aims at early detection, adequate treatment, and follow-up of the patients to ensure proper compliance.

Related Pearl: Classification of blood pressure for adults - European Society of Cardiology guidelines - 2018

Classification of Office blood pressure

SBP (mmHg)

DBP (mmHg)

Optimal 

<120 and

<80

Normal

120-129 and/or

80-84

High normal

130-139 and/or

85-89

Grade 1 hypertension

140-159 and/or

90-99

Grade 2 hypertension

160-179 and/or

100-109
Grade 3 hypertension ≥180 and/or ≥110
Isolated systolic hypertension ≥140 and <90

Note: Whenever hypertension can be classified into two different categories based on values of SBP and DBP, then the higher category is considered as the classification of hypertension.

questions.text: During a routine medical examination, a 50-year-old patient suddenly experiences profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea, followed by rapid shallow breathing. The physician suspects the activation of a reflex mechanism known as the Bezold-Jarisch reflex. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for triggering this kind of reflex?
questions.solution:
Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine.

questions.text: Which of the following agency provides seed and manure in applied nutrition programs in schools?
questions.solution:
UNICEF provides seed and manure in applied nutrition programs in schools. 

Applied Nutrition Program is implemented with the aim of producing various types of productive food by the community for the community itself.

UNICEF assists the program by providing implements, seeds, manure, and water supply equipment. If free land is available in schools, the facilities provided by UNICEF should be used in developing school gardens.

The produce obtained from the gardens can be utilized for school feeding programs and for nutrition education. 

Another strategy called GOBI was also implemented by UNICEF with the aim of a child health revolution. 

The GOBI-FFF strategy was given by United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF).

  • The GOBI-FFF strategy is aimed at child health revolution and survival.
  • It was called initially called the GOBI strategy, and the FFF aspect was later added to it.

Other options:

Option A: CARE- Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere aims at providing food for children in the age group of 6-11 years. It is also helping in projects like integrated nutrition and health project, better health and nutrition projects, anemia control projects, etc.

Option B: UNDP- The United Nations Development Program provides funds for technical assistance. Its main objective is to help poorer nations in developing their human and natural resources. 

Option D: WHO- World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life. 

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of fatigue, decreased exercise tolerance, and difficulty concentrating. Upon evaluation, the physician orders hormone-level testing to assess the patient's pituitary function. The graph below illustrates the fluctuations of a particular hormone over 24 hours. Which hormone is most likely depicted in the graph?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, (Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM Sleep)

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.text: While performing a tonsillectomy, the head surgeon holds the tonsil at its upper pole, applies traction downwards and medially and continues to dissect until the lower pole is reached. Which of the following is the instrument used for the next step of the surgery?
questions.solution:
Tonsillar snare is used in the next step of tonsillectomy, to cut and remove the tonsil.

During a tonsillectomy, the tonsil is held at its upper pole, and traction is applied downwards and medially. Dissection is continued until the lower pole is reached. In the next step, a tonsillar snare is used to thread the wired loop over the tonsil, cut its pedicle and remove it.

questions.text: A 30-day-old infant is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has a large and hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: Obstruction at the location labeled A in the image below would lead to the dilation of all the following cerebral ventricles or structures except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius, which connects the third ventricle with the fourth ventricle.

Blockage of the CSF flow, at the aqueduct would result in the distension of all the spaces proximal to it, which includes the third ventricle, interventricular foramen, and the lateral ventricles. Thus the fourth ventricle, which receives the CSF from the cerebral aqueduct does not get distended when the aqueduct is blocked.

The ventricular system is derived from the inner lumen of the developing neural tube. Lining the ventricles is the choroid plexus, consisting of modified ependymal cells responsible for producing the CSF. From the lateral ventricles, CSF flows through the interventricular foramen of Monro to the third ventricle. The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius, which courses through the midbrain. Surrounded by the pons and medulla anteriorly and the cerebellum posteriorly, the fourth ventricle sends CSF out of the ventricular system and into the subarachnoid space via the lateral foramina of Luschka and midline foramen of Magendie. 

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the 3rd ventricle

Boundaries of the 3rd ventricle

Roof - Choroid plexus

Lateral wall - Thalamus, hypothalamus

Anterior wall - Anterior commissure, Lamina terminalis

Posterior wall - Pineal gland, Posterior commissure, Aqueduct of Sylvius

Floor - Optic chiasma, Infundibulum, mamillary bodies, posterior perforating substance, tegmentum of midbrain

questions.text: A patient with complaints of nasal obstruction and nasal discharge was diagnosed to be a case of an antrochoanal polyp. All of the following statements are true about the condition except
questions.solution:
All of the above statements about the antrochoanal polyp are true except it is bilateral.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation of choice: Nasal endoscopy. Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: Echocardiography of a patient showed mitral stenosis with vegetation present on the mitral valve. The image of the histopathological study of the vegetation is given below. Identify the finding.
questions.solution:
The image of the histopathological study depicts Aschoff bodies. This feature is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. During acute rheumatic fever, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart. 

Chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening and fibrosis of the valve leaflets, often with calcific deposits. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish mouth appearance (buttonhole).

Other options:

Option B: Ferruginous bodies are histopathologic findings in interstitial lung disease suggestive of asbestosis (significant asbestos exposure).

Option C: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are a histological feature characteristic of malakoplakia which is a rare inflammatory condition that typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals mainly affecting the urinary tract.

Option D: Spider cells are seen in Rhabdomyoma.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis ?
questions.solution:
Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

questions.text:
A patient scheduled for a CABG procedure receives preoperative heparin for anticoagulation. During the surgery, the patient starts bleeding massively and there is a drop in BP. Which of the following would you use to manage this patient?

CABG: Coronary Artery Bypass Graft
questions.solution:
Protamine sulfate is the drug used to treat life-threatening, heparin-induced bleeding.

It is a mixture of basic polypeptides isolated from salmon sperm. It binds to acidic heparin with high affinity and neutralizes anticoagulant activity. The resultant protamine-heparin complexes are cleared. Protamine binds only to long heparin molecules (UFH). Therefore, protamine only partially reverses the activity of LMWH and has no effect on fondaparinux. 

It is most commonly used to neutralize heparin-induced anticoagulation after separation from cardiopulmonary bypass. It is also utilized in the setting of dialysis, invasive vascular procedures, and acute ischemic strokes.

Note: Protamine sulfate has anticoagulant activity at higher doses and hence, only small amounts of protamine (1mg/100 units of heparin) are used for heparin-induced bleeding.

Related Pearl: Heparin vs. LMWH vs. Fondaparinux

Knowing the structural difference (scroll down for the image) between the three drugs is important to know why the three drugs act differently. 

Features Unfractionated heparin LMWH Fondaparinux
Structure

A glycosaminoglycan consisting of long saccharide chains

 A glycosaminoglycan consisting of short saccharide chains A synthetic pentasaccharide
Factor Xa inhibition  Yes Yes Yes
Factor IIa inhibition

Yes (Xa = IIa)

The long chains act Xa and IIa equally.

Yes (Xa > IIa)

LMWH contains a mixture of long and short chains.

No

The pentasaccharide has no action on factor IIa
Bioavailability

Oral: Not absorbed

S.C.: Not good (longer chains are not absorbed well) 

I.V.: Good

Oral: Not absorbed

S.C.: Good 

Oral: Not absorbed

S.C.: Very good
Variable response Yes  No No
Metabolism (longer chains) Cleared by the reticuloendothelial system  Cleared by the kidneys Cleared by the kidneys
Safety in renal disease Safe in renal impairment Used with close monitoring Contraindicated in renal failure
Monitoring  Required, with aPTT Required only in renal impairment, with anti-factor Xa assay Not required
Protamine sulfate as antidote Full reversal Partial reversal (acts only on the longer chains) No reversal
Risk of Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia High  Lower Least
Risk of osteoporosis Occasionally Lower Lower

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly identifies the gland responsible for secreting ptyalin?
questions.solution:
Ptyalin (salivary α-amylase) is secreted by the salivary gland.

There are 3 pairs of salivary glands:

  1. Parotid
  2. Submandibular
  3. Sublingual glands

Ptyalin plays a crucial role in the initial digestion of carbohydrates in the mouth. It breaks down starch molecules into smaller polysaccharides, maltose, and dextrins. This process begins the digestion of carbohydrates in the oral cavity before food enters the stomach and continues in the small intestine with the action of pancreatic amylase.

Other options:

Option A: Gastric gland - Gastric glands secrete gastric juices containing hydrochloric acid and enzymes such as pepsin, which primarily aid in the digestion of proteins. Ptyalin is not secreted by gastric glands.

Option B: Duodenal gland - The duodenal glands, also known as Brunner's glands, secrete mucus-rich alkaline fluid that helps neutralize acidic chyme entering the duodenum from the stomach. Ptyalin is not secreted by duodenal glands.

Option D: Pancreatic gland - The pancreatic gland secretes pancreatic juice, which contains enzymes such as pancreatic amylase, lipase, and proteases, involved in the digestion of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. While pancreatic amylase aids in carbohydrate digestion, ptyalin is specifically secreted by the salivary glands.

questions.text: A patient is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Identify the correct pair of the serological test and culture media from the following.

choices.text: Elek Gel precipitation test - Potassium tellurite agar

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine is suggestive of infection with Leptospirosis(Weil's disease). The microscopic agglutination test is the serological test used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used for leptospira. 

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by leptospira. Humans are infected when the leptospires in water contaminated by the urine of carrier animals enter the body through cuts or abrasions on the skin or through the intact mucosa of the mouth, nose, or conjunctiva.

Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache, and intense injection of the eyes. Some may present as aseptic meningitis or with hepatorenal damage (Weil's disease).

Diagnosis includes:

Microscopy:

  • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from the blood after 1 week.
  • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposits of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.

Culture: With semisynthetic media like EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.

Serotype-specific tests:

  • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
  • Macroscopic agglutination test  
  • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option B: Elek Gel precipitation test - Potassium tellurite agar is for Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Option C: Ascoli's thermoprecipitation test - PLET medium is for Bacillus anthracis.

Option D: Cold agglutination test – Eaton’s agar is for Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

questions.text: Which nerve from the image given below gives rise to the anterior interosseous nerve?
questions.solution:
The anterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the median nerve marked as 1. 

The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and damage to the nerve prevents flexion of the index finger.

Relations of the third part of the axillary artery: 

Anterior: Pectoralis major, skin and fascia, the medial root of the median nerve

Posterior: Lower part of subscapularis and tendons of lattisimus dorsi and teres major, radial, and axillary nerves

Lateral: Coracobrachialis, musculocutaneous nerve (for a short distance), Lateral root, and then the trunk of the median nerve

Medial: Axillary vein, medial cutaneous nerve of forearm, Ulnar nerve

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of the synthesis of thyroid hormones in order.
  1. Oxidation
  2. Coupling reaction
  3. Transport via sodium-iodide symporter
  4. Organification/Iodination
  5. Transport via pendrin
questions.solution:
The formation of thyroid hormones starts with the trapping of iodine via sodium-iodide symporter and its transport into the follicle via pendrin. This is followed by oxidation, organification, and coupling reaction.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (Option 3) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter (Option 5).
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloids.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation (Option 1): TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2 
    • Organification (Option 4): TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions (Option 2): TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves produces the extraocular movement as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows an elevation of the eye in adduction. It caused by the inferior oblique muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

Innervation of extraocular muscles:

  • Trochlear nerve (IV CN) innervates the superior oblique muscle.
  • Abducens nerve (VI CN) innervates the lateral rectus muscle.
  • The oculomotor nerve (III CN) innervates all the remaining muscles, which include: Superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles; and inferior oblique muscle.

 

Related Pearl: Extraocular muscles and their actions

Muscle Primary action Secondary action Tertiary action
Superior rectus Elevation Intorsion Adduction
Inferior rectus Depression Extorsion Adduction
Medial rectus Adduction --- --- 
Lateral rectus Abduction ---- ---
Superior oblique Intorsion Depression Abduction
Inferior oblique Extorsion Elevation Abduction

questions.text: A patient died due to poisoning with a substance that inhibits the complex of the electron transport chain that is marked in the image below. Which of the following is likely to be the substance?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the complex of the electron transport chain shown is complex IV and carbon monoxide inhibits complex IV.

Molecules like glucose undergo a series of oxidation reactions to produce CO2 and water. The metabolic intermediates of these reactions donate electrons to NAD and FAD to form NADH and FADH2. They, in turn, donate a pair of electrons to a specialized set of electron carriers called the electron transport chain. 

The electron chain is present in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It has are 4 protein complexes, named complex-I, II, III, and IV. These complexes are connected by two carriers- co-enzyme Q and cytochrome C. The complexes and their inhibitors are summarized below.

Complexes of ETC   Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase Carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL(British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV:  cytochrome c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

 

The following image shows different compounds inhibiting the different components in an electron transport chain.

questions.text: A peripheral smear of a patient having myelodysplastic syndrome is shown below. Identify the finding.
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows pseudo-pledger huet cells (neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes and occasionally neutrophils that completely lack nuclear segmentation) which are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome. 

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after the toxic drug or radiation exposure with a poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections, and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, the most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

Other options:

Option A: Ringed sideroblasts are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules in Prussian blue stained aspirates or biopsy.

Option B: Pawn ball megakaryocytes are megakaryocytes with single nuclear lobes or multiple separate nuclei.

Option C: Dohle bodies represent the dilated endoplasmic reticulum. They appear as blue-colored inclusions inside neutrophils. These inclusions may be seen in conditions such as sepsis and myelodysplastic syndromes.

Related Pearl: Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series appears as

  • Ring sideroblasts- Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm
  • Megaloblastoid maturation- Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities- Nucleus with abnormal shape

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series 

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes- 

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A patient comes to the clinic complaining of recurrent oral and genital ulcers. Further evaluation shows an association with the HLA -B51 haplotype. Identify the likely diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The presentation of a patient with recurrent oral aphthous ulcers and genital ulcers, associated with HLA haplotype B51 is likely to be a diagnosis of Behcet disease.

Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Here (Th17) T helper 17 cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall. 

There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. The condition is treated with steroids, cyclophosphamide, and TNF antagonists.

Other options:

Option A: Goodpasture's syndrome is an anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) antibody-mediated disease. The antibodies are directed against the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. As it is present in both the alveoli and GBM, it usually presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and renal failure.

Option B: Takayasu arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It mainly affects the aortic arch and its branches. The most commonly affected artery is the subclavian artery. Patients will present with features of arm claudication, Raynaud's phenomenon, etc. They can also present with syncope, transient ischemic attack, abdominal pain, or chest pain depending on the arteries involved. A biopsy of the affected artery will show pan arteritis with mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells. Takayasu arteritis is not associated with migratory thrombophlebitis.

Option D: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

 

Related Pearl: HLA Associations with diseases

Autoimmune Gut and Skin Diseases and HLA associations
