questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in breathing and swallowing. On examination, a painless nasopharyngeal mass was noted as shown in the image below. Angiofibroma was suspected. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a nasopharyngeal mass suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), which is causing difficulty in breathing and swallowing. It is more common in males. 

The tumor is predominantly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life. It is thought to be testosterone dependent. Patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx which is activated to form angiofibroma when male sex hormones appear.

A biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of severe bleeding. The vessels lack contractile components and hence bleeding cannot be controlled with adrenaline.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows Schwartze sign, which is seen in active otosclerosis.

A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous diarrhea with rice water stools. A microscopic examination of a stool sample is shown in the image below. All the following can be used as a transport medium for this causative organism except?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of rice water stools and the image showing the characteristic fish in stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae for which Stuart media cannot be used as a transport medium. Stuart media is used as a transport medium for the Neisseria group of organisms.

Transport media for Vibrio cholerae include: 

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary Blair medium
  • Autoclaved seawater.  

Enrichment media for Vibrio cholerae include:

  • Alkaline peptone water at a pH of 8.6
  • Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water at a pH of 9.2.

Both these enrichment media are good transport mediums as well.

*Note - School of fish appearance (aka railroad appearance) is seen with Haemophilus ducreyi (as shown below).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or experimental studies.

The bias that are seen in the case-control study are:

  1. Confounding
  2. Recall bias
  3. Selection bias
  4. Berkesonian bias
  5. Interviewer's bias

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

questions.text: Angular conjunctivitis is caused by _______.
questions.solution:
Moraxella species,which are gram negative diplobacillus are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the inner and outer canthi with excoriation of skin and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.

Causes: 

  • Moraxella axenfeld
  • Moraxella lacunata
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause) 

Source of infection: Nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis

Mode of spread: From the nasal cavity to the eye by contaminated hands and handkerchief

Treatment

  • Oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days 
  • Zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic ferment.

questions.text: A child presents with generalised edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urine analysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

Glomerular diseases associated with heavy proteinuria clinically manifests as Nephrotic Syndrome.

The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome :

  1. Hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL)
  2. Edema
  3. Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol> 200 mg/dL)

along with proteinuria > 3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio > 2 to warrant a diagnosis of Nephrotic Syndrome.

Causes of nephrotic syndrome :

Primary/Idiopathic - 

  • Minimal change disease (most common)
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
  • Membranous nephropathy
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Secondary to diseases such as :

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus,
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura,
  • Malignancies (lymphoma and leukemia)
  • Infections (hepatitis, HIV, and malaria)

Other options :

Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) nephritis
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Goodpasture syndrome (Option C)
  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Urine flow rate is 10 mL/min; plasma inulin is 2 mg/mL; and urine inulin is 25 mg/mL.Which of the following is true assuming GFR to be normal?
questions.solution:
Inulin clearance is calculated by the formula:

Substituting the values given,

  • Uinulin= 25 mg/mL
  • Vinulin= 10 mL/min
  • Pinulin=2 mg/mL

Thus, Inulin clearance=GFR (normal GFR= 125 ml/min)

NOTE: 

Inulin is a polymer of fructose, clearance of inulin can be used for measurement of GFR, because of the following reasons: 

  • Freely filtered
  • Neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules
  • Nontoxic
  • Not metabolized by the body.

questions.text: The new online RNTCP software launched by the government to monitor the TB control programme is called:
questions.solution:
Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients.

Nikusth is a web-based solution for monitoring Leprosy patients.

eDOT is an electronic form of DOT to observe patients taking treatment for TB by video. It is an intiative of CDC and currently not available in India.

Nischay is a pregnancy test kit.

questions.text: There is a group of 200 hypertensive patients. First group of 100 patients is given medical advice whereas a second group of 100 patients is advised lifestyle changes. Which of the following tests of significance is used to compare the blood pressure after 3 months ?
questions.solution:
The unpaired t-test is used to test the difference between two groups or means when the samples are independent of each other. Here, the blood pressure of the two groups who are given different interventions is being compared, which are independent of each other.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe muscle pain and fatigue after engaging in strenuous exercise. Upon examination, his blood lactate levels are found to be elevated. Further investigation reveals a deficiency in an enzyme crucial for the conversion of lactate back to glucose in the liver and kidney cells. Which cycle will be primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle. It links gluconeogenesis and anaerobic glycolysis.

Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and RBCs. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Significance: The cycle's importance is based on the prevention of lactic acidosis in the muscle under anaerobic conditions. However, normally before this happens the lactic acid is moved out of the muscles and into the liver.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called the glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from skeletal muscle obtained from glycolysis of muscle glycogen. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Kreb's cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D- Urea cycle is also known as the Krebs–Henseleit cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with erectile dysfunction, his internal pudendal artery was found to be stenosed. Which of the following​ vessels is this a branch of?

choices.text: Anterior division of internal iliac artery
Posterior division of internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to the internal pudendal artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior division of internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery(in males)
  • Inferior vesical artery (in males)
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior division of internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle ​cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hurthle cells are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase in the vast majority of Hashimoto patients.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, which contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

questions.text: The structures marked as A, B, C & D in the histological image of the skin given below are respectively:

choices.text: Stratum corneum, Stratum lucidum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum basale
Stratum lucidum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum basale
Stratum corneum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum basale
Stratum corneum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum basale

questions.solution:
The image shows the histological appearance of the epidermis of the skin. The structures marked are respectively:

  • A- Stratum corneum
  • B- Stratum granulosum
  • C- Stratum spinosum
  • D- Stratum basale

The above 4 layers are present in the thin hairy skin. 

The thick glabrous skin over the palms and the soles alone contains a clear homogenous 5th layer between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum, called the stratum lucidum. 

Layers of epidermis:

questions.text: How does the Jendrassik manoeuvre reinforce the knee jerk reflex?

choices.text: Activates group 1b nerve fibres in tendon
Decreases activity of group 1a nerve fibres

questions.solution:
Jendrassik's maneuver reinforces the knee-jerk reflex by increasing the gamma motor neuron discharge from the spinal cord. Increased gamma motor discharge increases the sensitivity of group 1a nerve fibers in the muscle spindles to stretch. Increased activity of the group 1a afferents enhances deep tendon reflexes, including the knee jerk reflex.

The maneuver can also enhance reflexes by distracting the subject and preventing conscious inhibition.

Other options:

Group 1b fibres in the Golgi tendon organ are activated in the inverse stretch reflex.

questions.text: A student on mapping DNA replication reads about Bloom’s syndrome. Choose the correct option regarding the enzyme deficiency present in the condition.

choices.text: It causes unwinding of DNA template

questions.solution:
Bloom syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with genomic instability. It is due to a defective homologous repair in the BLM gene located at Chromosome 15. The BLM gene codes for the enzyme DNA helicase which helps in unwinding the DNA.

The clinical features are short stature, photosensitivity, and telangiectatic erythema. It predisposes to the development of childhood leukemia and most types of cancer. 

Defect in helicase enzyme is also associated with an increased risk of development of Werner syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia.

Other options

Option A: DNA primase initiates the synthesis of RNA primers.

Option C: Single-stranded DNA binding proteins (SSB) prevent rewinding of DNA.

Option D: Topoisomerases relieve the torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations?
questions.solution:
500-600 ml of transient loss/insensible loss per day would have to be accounted for in the calculation.

Although water is lost through sweating especially in hot climates or during physical exertion, we tend to lose water at rest as well. Physiologically, water evaporates from the skin and lungs at a rate of about 600 to 700 ml/day. This is known as insensible water loss.

questions.text: A Molotov cocktail is a type of:
questions.solution:
Molotov cocktail is an incendiary bomb.

  • Molotov cocktail is an incendiary bomb which is thrown by hand.
  • In a crude type of this bomb, a bottle is filled with gasoline and a rag to serve as a wick, the wick is lit and thrown at the target.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child with weakness of limbs and difficulty in walking was evaluated. Serum creatinine kinase was elevated. A sex-linked recessive mode of inheritance was seen.  What is the condition the boy is suffering from?
questions.solution:
A 3-year-old male child with limb weakness, difficulty walking, elevated creatinine kinase, and sex-linked inheritance is likely to suffer from Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

It is an X-linked recessive disease and is due to a mutation in a structural protein called dystrophin. Males are commonly affected. They are normal at birth. Symptoms of weakness gradually develop and are often characterized by delayed walking, clumsiness, and inability to keep up with peers. 

Pelvic girdle muscles are affected and this is followed by shoulder girdle weakness. Muscles of the lower leg are weak but enlarged, described as pseudohypertrophy. Other features include cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and intellectual disability.

Serum creatine kinase is markedly elevated. Supportive treatment is needed. 

Other options:

Option A: Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting multiple systems. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy.

Option B: A limb-girdle dystrophy is a heterogeneous group characterized by autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant types. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness with variable age of onset and severity

Option C: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant type characterized by weakness of facial muscles and shoulder girdle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve?

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent.
Drug B is the most efficacious.
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D.
Drug A is more potent than drug B.

questions.solution:
The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Hence, Drug B is the most potent.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • In the above image, the potency is Drug B> Drug A > Drug C > Drug D.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug C =Drug D > Drug B.
  • Drugs having a similar pharmacological effect can have different efficacies e.g furosemide and metolazone are both diuretics but furosemide has greater efficacy than metolazone.

questions.text: A young patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. A provisional diagnosis of hemisection of the spinal cord was made. Which of the following findings will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Contralateral weakness and spasticity of muscle groups.
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemisection of the spinal cord following a road traffic accident is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome. A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have an ipsilateral loss of vibration sense.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor. The clinical features are:

Structures injured Effects of injury below the level of the lesion
Fasciculus gracilis and  cuneatus Ipsilateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception
Corticospinal tract Ipsilateral weakness and spasticity of specific muscle groups
Spinothalamic tract Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is interested in incorporating more antioxidants into their diet to promote overall health. He inquires about which vitamin is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant. What is the right vitamin for this patient?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant.

Protective antioxidant nutrients:

  • Selenium
  • Vitamin C
  • Vitamin E
  • β-carotene (vitamin A)and other carotenoids
  • Polyphenolic compounds derived from plant foods

Therapeutic uses of high dose of Vitamin E:

1) Retrolental fibroplasia

2) Bronchopulmonary dysplasia

3) Intraventricular hemorrhage

4) Used for treatment of intermittent claudication.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding phase.

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rates and death rates within a population, leading to changes in population size and age structure.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: The establishment bearing the following logo would provide services aimed at ______.
questions.solution:
The Suraksha Clinics are for management of sexually transmitted diseases and patients are given color-coded kits.

The kits are

  • Kit 1– grey, for urethra discharge, painful scrotal swelling, and cervicitis.
  • Kit 2– green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3– white, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4– blue, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 5– red, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 6– yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7– black, for inguinal bubo.
  • Kit 8– brown, for anorectal discharge

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presented with sore throat and pain in her right ear. On examination, the pharyngeal wall was red and inflamed suggestive of pharyngitis. The structure through which the infection has spread to the middle ear, opens in the nasopharynx at which of the following sites?

choices.text: Behind posterior end of inferior turbinate

questions.solution:
The pharyngotympanic tube / eustachian tube opens approximately behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate, in the lateral wall of nasopharynx.

The eustachian tube connects the nasopharynx and the tympanic cavity in the middle ear. It is usually collapsed and opens during activities such as yawning or swallowing. Its function is to maintain the pressure in the middle ear cavity and drain any secretions from the middle ear.

Clinical significance:

  • Upper respiratory tract infections may spread to the middle ear through the eustachian tube.
  • In cases of eustachian tube dysfunction, secretions may accumulate in the middle ear cavity, which may allow bacteria or viruses grow leading to a condition called otitis media.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is involved in the process of oxidative deamination?
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is involved in the process of oxidative deamination. In contrast to transamination (transfer amino groups), oxidative deamination by glutamate dehydrogenase results in the liberation of the amino group as free ammonia.

Glutamate dehydrogenase can use NADH or NADPH during oxidative deamination.

questions.text: A diabetic patient diagnosed with Covid 19 infection on steroid therapy presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and redness of the right eye. There is significant visual impairment. On examination, there is a blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. 

Invasive Mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia/uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids/ immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

MUCORMYCOSIS:

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of rhizopus, mucor, and lichtheimia. Among them, the most prevalent species are Rhizopus oryzae and R. delemar. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. They invade tissues of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels particularly paranasal sinuses and orbit. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis- They can be stained with 10% potassium hydroxide and can be cultured.

On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.

Under the microscope, they appear as nonseptate, irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

The below image shows broad aseptate and irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis

Treatment: Surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration (1st line agent). Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole.

Amphotericin B:

This is available in 3 forms

  • Amphotericin B deoxycholate- It is inexpensive but is highly toxic and has poor nervous system penetration
  • Liposomal amphotericin B- It has better nervous system penetration, better outcome than amphotericin B deoxycholate. It is very expensive.
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex- It is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate but expensive.

Important side effects are:

  • Infusion-related toxicity- fever, chills, muscle spasms, vomiting, headache, and hypotension.
  • Nephrotoxicity- It is seen in nearly all patients treated with amphotericin B.
  • Liver damage
  • Seizures and arachnoiditis may develop after intrathecal therapy.

 

Other forms:

  • Pulmonary mucormycosis- It is the second commonest form and presents with fever, dyspnea, cough, and chest pain.
  • Cutaneous mucormycosis- It usually results after trauma or any penetrating injury to the skin. The infection can penetrate into fascia, muscle, and bone.
  • Gastrointestinal mucormycosis- It primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated disease or necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • Disseminated mucormycosis- The infection from the primary site can disseminate to the brain, bones, mediastinum, etc.

questions.text: A patient who was hospitalized and started on an intravenous antibiotic has developed diarrhea. The findings of the colonoscopy are given below. Which of the following antibiotic is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis most likely due to clindamycin. 

Pseudomembranous colitis is an advanced form of clostridium difficile infection (CDI) that is visualized at endoscopy. Pseudomembranes are seen as whitish yellow plaques on the mucosa. Clostridium difficile infection is the most commonly diagnosed nosocomial diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, that causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora. This leads to the colonization of C. difficile.

Antibiotics that may cause CDI are:

  • Clindamycin
  • Ampicillin
  • Cephalosporins- cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime
  • Fluroquinolones- ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin

Clinical features include diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria: 

  • Diarrhea without other recognized causes, and
  • Detection of toxin A or B in the stool, toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool 

Discontinuation of the offending antimicrobial, if possible, is the first step in management. Oral vancomycin and fidaxomicin (Option B) are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

Other options:

Option A: Daptomycin may cause allergic pneumonitis in patients receiving prolonged therapy for more than 2 weeks.

Option D: Chloramphenicol is mainly associated with adverse effects such as bone marrow suppression, and hypersensitivity reactions. When given to infants, it may cause grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Echocardiography showed mitral stenosis with vegetation. The vegetation present on the mitral valve was excised and its HPE image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given HPE image depicts Aschoff bodies, suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. During acute rheumatic fever, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart. 

Chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening and fibrosis of the valve leaflets, often with calcific deposits. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish mouth appearance (button hole).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Upon examination, he appears overweight and reports a history of excessive dietary intake. Considering his clinical presentation, which of the following enzymes is likely to exhibit high activity in this patient?
questions.solution:
In individuals in a well-fed state, such as the patient described, the activity of acetyl CoA carboxylase is elevated. This enzyme plays a crucial role in fatty acid synthesis (lipogenesis), which is favoured during periods of nutrient abundance.

Acetyl CoA carboxylase in the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid synthesis (anabolic pathway).

In the well-fed state,

  • There is an abundant supply of glucose, which is converted to pyruvate and in-turn acetyl CoA.
  • Acetyl CoA enters into fatty acid synthesis
  • The fatty acids thus formed (most commonly palmitoyl CoA) are esterified into triacylglycerols. This is called lipogenesis.
  • Also, there is high insulin: glucagon ratio in the well-fed state, which favors dephosphorylation of acetyl CoA carboxylase, resulting in its activation.

Note: The enzymes Acyl CoA dehydrogenase, Thiolase, and Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I are involved in fatty acid oxidation and are inactive in the well-fed state.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) as it re-establishes the lacrimal drainage.

One of the sequelae of chronic dacryocystitis is mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician complaining of fatigue and weakness. Upon further questioning, she reports a history of recurrent episodes of confusion and difficulty concentrating. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of methylmalonic acid in her urine. In patients with elevated levels of methylmalonic acid, which of the following statements regarding propionyl CoA is true?

choices.text: Propionyl CoA is produced by the oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids.
Methylmalonyl CoA mutase is a biotin-dependent enzyme.
Odd-chain fatty acids do not undergo oxidation.

questions.solution:
Propionyl CoA is produced by the oxidation of fatty acids containing an odd number of carbon atoms.

In the oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids, the last cycle of oxidation yields a three-carbon containing propionyl CoA. Propionyl CoA is carboxylated to methylmalonyl CoA by propionyl CoA carboxylase, a biotin-dependent enzyme, which requires the hydrolysis of ATP. Methylmalonyl CoA is further converted into succinyl CoA by racemase and mutase, (a vitamin B12 dependent enzyme) which enters into the TCA cycle.

Thus, propionyl CoA can be converted into glucose by gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A lethargic infant was presented with vomiting and irritability. He was diagnosed with an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a deficiency in enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is likely to have a diagnosis of type 2 hyperammonemia inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate leading to elevated levels of glutamine in the blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

Infants present with vomiting, irritability, lethargy, hypothermia, and apnea due to high ammonia levels in the plasma. Mothers also have an aversion to protein-rich foods. 

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea namely ammonia, and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

  1. Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.
  2. Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.
  3. Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
  4. Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
  5. Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
  6. Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: The COVID-19 outbreak is a type of ______________
questions.solution:
This outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a Propagated epidemic.

The propagated epidemic results from a person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. In this scenario, the cases of COVID occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. Other examples of a propagated epidemic include Hepatitis A and Polio.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics:

  Point source, single exposure epidemic Point source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A teenager comes to the emergency room with profuse bleeding from the nose. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which part of the septum is it located in?
questions.solution:
The Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area which is present at the anteroinferior part of the septum.

Bleeding from inside the nose is called epistaxis and often presents as an emergency. Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases.

Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach’s plexus. This area is exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual site for epistaxis in children and young adults.

The four contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery, which supplies the nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Blood supply of the nose:

Nasal Septum:

  • Internal carotid system
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery - branch of ophthalmic artery
    • Posterior ethmoidal artery - branch of ophthalmic artery
  • External carotid system 
    • Nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches from the sphenopalatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Septal branch of greater palatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Septal branch of superior labial artery - branch of facial artery

Lateral wall

  • Internal carotid system
    • Anterior ethmoidal - branch of ophthalmic artery
    • Posterior ethmoidal - branch of ophthalmic artery
  • External carotid system
    • Posterior lateral nasal branches from the sphenopalatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Greater palatine artery - branch of maxillary artery
    • Nasal branch of anterior superior dental artery - infraorbital branch of maxillary artery
    • Branches of facial artery to nasal vestibule

questions.text: Project “Axshya” is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means ‘free from TB’ which is the ultimate goal of the project and the national TB programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by The International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services,
  • Community participation in TB care and control,
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

World Tuberculosis Day, observed on 24 March each year, is designed to build public awareness about the global epidemic of tuberculosis and efforts to eliminate the disease. The theme for 2019 is 'It's time'.

questions.text: Fleischer's ring is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Fleischer's ring is seen in keratoconus. Slit-lamp examination reveals Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone formed.

Keratoconus or the conical cornea is a bilateral non-inflammatory progressive condition of the axial part of the cornea. Central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea are pathognomonic. This is attributed to mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue synthesis defects. 

Clinical features of the condition include defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism. Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present. Complications include acute hydrops following the rupture of Descemet's membrane.

Deep, vertical stromal striae (Vogt lines) that disappear with external pressure are characteristic. Retinoscopy shows a scissoring reflex. The bulging of the lower lid in the downgaze, called Munson's sign, is shown in the image below.

The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry. Corneal topography is a diagnostic modality with the highest sensitivity for early cases.

Intacs or intracorneal ring segments are useful in moderate cases due to their flattening effect. Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses, corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin, and keratoplasty are the other treatment modalities.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A patient presents with memory deficits and difficulty in forming new memories. Upon examination, imaging reveals abnormalities in the structure marked in the image below. Fibers of this structure originate from which of the following?
questions.solution: This is a coronal section of the brain and the marked structure is the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mammillary body of the hypothalamus.

questions.text: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm H20)?
questions.solution:
Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure.

  • C= ΔV/ΔP

In this case,

ΔV= 1000 mL

ΔP= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O

The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration

Therefore the compliance is,

C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.text: A patient presents with hypercholesterolemia, prompting the clinician to review the biochemistry of cholesterol synthesis. Which of the following compounds serves as the primary precursor for cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA mainly in the liver, adrenal cortex, testes, ovaries, and intestine.

The enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis are partly located in the endoplasmic reticulum and partly in the cytoplasm. The enzyme HMG-CoA reductase is the principal enzyme involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

Cholesterol regulates the expression of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When cholesterol is less, proteases in the golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG-CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG-CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG-CoA reductase

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with stoke and his visual field testing revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The likely site of the lesion is occipital lobe as the image shows homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the audiology clinic with complaints of hearing difficulty in one of her ears. She reports a gradual onset of hearing loss over the past few months. An audiogram is obtained and presented below. Interpret the given audiogram:
questions.solution:
The audiogram indicates abnormalities in both bone conduction (BC) and air conduction (AC) thresholds in the left ear. The blue colour indicates the left ear, and the symbols indicate the thresholds for BC and AC. In both cases, the thresholds are above the normal range (BC >25 dB and AC >15 dB), suggesting sensorineural hearing loss.

Additionally, there is an air-bone gap present, indicating a difference between the AC and BC thresholds, which implies conductive hearing loss. Therefore, based on the combination of sensorineural and conductive components, the interpretation is left mixed hearing loss

Interpretation:

  • Blue color indicates left ear.
  • › indicates BC (Bone Conduction) and threshold is >25 dB. Hence BC is abnormal → sensorineural pathway is abnormal.
  • × indicates AC (Air Conduction) and threshold is >15 dB. Hence AC is abnormal.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, Air-Bone gap is present which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence interpreted as left mixed hearing loss.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for the management of coronary artery disease. Following the procedure, the patient was started on an antiplatelet agent to prevent thrombotic events. This medication is an irreversible inhibitor of P2Y12 receptors on platelets. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have been initiated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ticlopidine is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of the platelet.

Side effects of Ticlopidine include Diarrhea (most common), abdominal pain, headache, tinnitus, and skin rash. Serious adverse effects include thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and neutropenia.

Other options:

Option A: Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Ticagrelor is a reversible inhibitor of the P2Y12 receptor of the platelets.

Option C: Nifedipine is not an antiplatelet agent and is a calcium channel blocker useful in conditions like high blood pressure.

questions.text: A male patient came with a history of fever that had persisted for 3 weeks. Investigations reveal vegetation in the mitral valve and community-acquired native valve endocarditis was suspected. Identify the most common organism associated with the aetiology of this condition.
questions.solution:
Streptococci are the most common organism associated with community-acquired native valve endocarditis. They are also associated with causing late prosthetic valve endocarditis.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism overall to cause endocarditis.

Most common organisms causing endocarditis after implantation of prosthetic valves:

  • <2 months: Coagulase-negative staphylococci > Staphylococcus aureus
  • 2-12 months: Coagulase-negative staphylococci
  • >12 months: Streptococci > Staphylococcus aureus

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

 Condition

Most common organism

Staphylococcus aureus

Streptococci

Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side) Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side) Enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organism causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)*

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis (MG).

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR.

Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal.

questions.text: A cardiologist is conducting a research study on the phases of ventricular muscle action potential to better understand cardiac physiology. In the experiment, the cardiologist observes the different phases as shown below. Which phase of the ventricular muscle action potential corresponds to the closure of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and causes sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 
  • Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phase 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the a decrease in efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the lateral pterygoid muscle?
questions.solution:
The action of the lateral pterygoid muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted into the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - It originates from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the infratemporal surface of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.
  • Insertion - The muscle inserts into the neck of the condyle of the mandible and the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the lateral surface of the ramus of the mandible and coronoid process

Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of the temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - The upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. The superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: During a microbiology experiment, the gene for diphtheria toxin from Corynebacterium diphtheriae is carried on corynebacteriophages, and the toxin is produced only by the bacteria that are lysogenized by the phages. Which of the following methods of horizontal gene transfer is outlined in the above example?
questions.solution:
The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: A scientist is trying to develop a drug for a genetic condition. He seeks a drug that could cause epigenetic alteration in the DNA and could prevent the disease or seemingly improve the condition. All the following would include epigenetic modifications, except _______.

choices.text: Altering the gene sequence of DNA
DNA methylation at CpG islands in promoter regions

questions.solution:
Epigenetic changes are heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. They alter gene expression without mutation.

The term “epigenetics” means “above genetics.” It refers to the regulatory mechanisms that do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather change the expression patterns, or function, of the DNA. Epigenetic mechanisms play key roles in the establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. It can cause both gene activation and inactivation.

Epigenetic modifications include

  1. DNA methylation- It is the covalent addition and subtraction of a methyl group to DNA. Methylation is typically done in cytosine preceding a guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. CpG islands are mainly present in the promoter region.
  2. Histone modifications such as acetylation, deacetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, etc. Acetylation of histone activates transcription, while deacetylation represses transcription.
  3. miRNA- micro RNA or miRNA are approximately 22 nucleotides long. They do not code. They bind to mRNA and inhibit its translation.

Clinical significance of epigenetic mechanisms:

  • Epigenetic modifications, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, are reversible, which makes them amenable for application in therapeutic intervention.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and DNA methylation inhibitors are being tested in the treatment of cancer. These agents inhibit transcriptional silencing and thus reverse the chromatin condensation in cancer cells.
  • These modifications include heritable changes such as X-inactivation and genomic imprinting, but they can also result from dynamic post-translational protein modifications in response to environmental influences such as diet, age, and drugs.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presented with signs and symptoms of essential tremor caused due to progressive degeneration of the cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. Which of the following cells are affected?
questions.solution:
The output of the cerebellar cortex is from the Purkinje cells. They form the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

The output of the whole cerebellum is from the deep cerebellar nuclei (Fastigial, Globose, Emboliform and Dentate).

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic with features of hypotonia, irritability, and exaggerated startle response. Development milestones were delayed. Fundoscopic examination revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypotonia, irritability, exaggerated startle response, delayed milestones, and the fundoscopic image showing the cherry-red spot point to the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. The enzyme deficient in this condition is β-hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. It is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adult-onset forms based on the age at onset and clinical features.

Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age. Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:

  • Muscle weakness (hypotonia)
  • Seizures
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Macrocephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Blindness
  • Developmental delay

The deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A and B causes Sandhoff's disease. The clinical manifestations of Sandhoff disease are similar to those of Tay-Sachs disease. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities.

Other options:

Option A: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused due to deficiency of α-Galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. Clinical features include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, corneal and lenticular opacities, and painful acroparesthesias. Angiokeratomas are dark red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate lesions, usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the bathing suit area) and the trunk.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It leads to demyelination and the patient has a neurodegenerative course.

Option D: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance. The intelligence of the child is normal.

questions.text: Kartagener syndrome is a triad of situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis. This condition is due to the defect in which of the following motor proteins?
questions.solution:
Kartagener’s Syndrome is due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia.

The primary defect in Kartagener’s Syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). PCD is also called as immotile cilia syndrome.

Primary ciliary dyskinesia

  • Defects in ciliary motor proteins lead to ciliary dysfunction. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.
  • Ciliary function is necessary during development to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. In its absence, their location becomes a matter of chance. As a result, approximately half of the patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have Kartagener syndrome, marked by situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality along with chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis.
  • Males with this condition tend to be infertile, as a result of sperm dysmotility due to impaired sperm flagella function.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to a gynaecologist with a history of abdominal pain and distension. Ultrasound imaging revealed a tumour in the right ovary. The serum level of inhibin is raised. Identify the finding noted from the histopathology of the tumour given below.
questions.solution:
For the given clinical scenario of a woman with a history of abdominal pain and distension, with raised inhibin levels, the most likely diagnosis is the Granulosa cell tumour in this patient. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours

Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles.

Granulosa cell tumours are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. It is divided into adult and juvenile granulosa cell tumours largely based on the age of the patient, but also on morphologic findings. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumours. Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumours

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: The finding on impedance audiometry in a long standing otosclerosis is  _____

choices.text: Ad graph with increased stapedial reflex
As graph with loss of stapedial reflex
As graph with increased stapedial reflex

questions.solution:
Impedance audiometer measures 2 parameters in the middle ear:

  • Tympanogram is a measure of the Tympanic membrane’s compliance or deflection to change in pressure. There are 5 types of graphs seen:
    • A: Normal individuals. It is the most common graph in general population.
    • As: Otosclerosis/Thick TM
    • Ad: Ossicular discontinuity/Thin TM
    • B: Perforation of TM
    • C: Eustachian tube Obstruction
  • Stapedial reflex: As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, stapedial reflex is lost.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant presents to the paediatrician with symptoms of breathing difficulties, feeding problems, and vomiting shortly after birth. On further evaluation, the infant exhibits hypotonia and a characteristic odour. What type of odour is commonly associated with multiple carboxylase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odour is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.

Multiple carboxylase deficiencies leads to defects in utilisation of biotin. In neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures and even coma may occur. Affected infants should be treated with biotin.

questions.text: The instrument used to measure corneal thickness is the _________
questions.solution:
The pachymeter is used to measure corneal thickness.

Options a and d: A keratometer (ophthalmometer) measures the curvature of the anterior surface of the cornea at two points about 1.25 mm on either side of its center.

Option c: Specular microscopy is the study of the corneal endothelium under a very high magnification (100 times greater than slit lamp biomicroscopy).

questions.text: A man who is a chronic alcoholic has abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and mucosal ulcers. A stool examination revealed the following. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with stool examination showing a large ovoid trophozoite with cilia all over the surface suggests balantidiasis, the causative organism for which is Balantidium coli. 

It is the only ciliated protozoan and is present as a commensal in the large intestine. It is mostly asymptomatic in healthy individuals. However, certain predisposing factors such as malnourishment, alcoholism, concurrent infection with Trichuris trichiura, or bacterial infection can cause clinical infection.

Clinical manifestations include mucosal ulcers, diarrhea, frank dysentery, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 

Diagnosis is by stool examination, showing the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in formed stools. Trophozoites are large in size, with a macronucleus and rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with a macronucleus.

The trophozoite is shown in the image below:

Treatment is with tetracycline 500 mg 4 times a day for 10 days. 

Other options:

Option A: Babesia infection causes babesiosis, which is a disease that resembles malaria. Diagnosis is by the examination of blood smears stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain, where Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring forms, like Plasmodium falciparum.

Option B: Cyclospora infection causes prolonged diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting which is more severe in immunocompromised individuals. On wet mount, oocysts are seen as red spheres when stained with acid-fast stain.

Option D: Isospora belli infection causes watery diarrhea that is self-limiting. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to your OPD with severe constipation. After ruling out pathological causes, which of the following is the safest to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Lactulose is safe to use in pregnant women with constipation.

Constipation in pregnancy:

Constipation is a common occurrence in pregnancy because of dietary alterations, anatomic impingement of a large uterus on the rectosigmoid, fluid shifts, decreased exercise levels, and reduced mobility. Pregnancy and pregnancy-related constipation increases the risk for developing haemorrhoids.

Treatment options include

  • Dietary changes - increased water intake, increased fibre in diet
  • Gentle exercises
  • Laxatives - Lactulose, an osmotic purgative, and Ispaghula, a bulk forming agent, are safe to use in pregnancy. 

Senna, bisacodyl, docusates and saline laxatives’ safety is unknown and hence it is better to avoid them.

Note:

Laxatives are drugs that promote bowel evacuation.

Classification of Laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming agents 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran
    • Psyllium, Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
    • PG analogue: Lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose
    • Lactitol
