questions.text: According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than _________.
questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than 1000.

The Factories Act, 1948 states the following regarding safety and welfare measures:

  • > 1000 workers – there should be a safety officer
  • > 500 workers – there should be a welfare officer
  • > 250 workers – a canteen should be provided
  • > 30 female workers- a crèche should be provided

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of using contact lenses over spectacles?
questions.solution:
Prismatic effects will be less in contact lenses as compared to spectacles.

In spectacles, the edge of the lens acts as a prism leading to prismatic effects. Due to the prismatic effect produced by the spectacles used in aphakia, patients can experience visual problems like roving-ring scotoma and jack-in-the-box phenomenon.

Contact lenses are artificial devices that act as a substitute for the anterior surface of the cornea. Contact lenses have multiple therapeutic uses. They include providing pain relief in bullous keratopathy by using soft bandage lenses as it protects the exposed corneal nerve endings from the eyelid's shearing forces during blinking.

Constant use can cause complications such as giant papillary conjunctivitis, superficial punctate keratitis, tight lens syndrome, and acute/chronic hypoxia.

Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of infection leading to acanthamoeba keratitis. This occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lenses with tap water

Inflammation can be a complication in contact lens users. A giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis, most commonly associated with contact lens wear. 

Contact lenses decrease corneal oxygen supply. The cornea obtains its O2 supply from the atmosphere. The use of contact lenses decreases the O2 supply from the atmosphere. Although dry eye is caused by wearing contact lenses, lenses made of hydrogel, which are high in water content are beneficial in dry eye.

Difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles include the following:

  • Image magnification by 25–30%
  • Spherical aberrations producing a “pin cushion effect”
  • Roving-ring scotoma is seen in the correction of aphakia with spectacles due to prismatic effects at the edge of the lens.
  • Jack-in-the-box phenomenon from the prismatic effects at the edge of the lens
  • Reduced visual fields
  • Physical inconvenience

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA(polymethylmethacrylate). 
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA - hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate

questions.text: A known cancer patient who underwent multiple cycles of chemotherapy developed tingling and numbness in the lower limbs. The symptoms progressed even after cessation of the cycles. Identify the causative anti-neoplastic drug.
questions.solution:
The scenario depicts coasting effect neuropathy, which is seen with Cisplatin.

The coasting effect means the progression of symptoms even after the cessation of the drug. Neurotoxicity is usually dependent on the cumulative dose of anticancer drugs. Usually, the severity of neuropathy increases with the duration of treatment and progression stops once drug treatment is completed. But in the case of Platinum compounds, sensory loss progresses for several months even after cessation of treatment.

The coasting effect is more common with cisplatin and oxaliplatin than with carboplatin.

Cisplatin is a potent anti-neoplastic agent widely used in tumours in the lung, bladder, oesophagus, stomach, and liver. It is very effective against head and neck, metastatic testicular and ovarian carcinoma. 

Adverse effects: Renal impairment, tinnitus, deafness, sensory neuropathy and hyperuricaemia.

questions.text: Examination of a long-term mine worker reveals the following finding shown in the image. He is also found to be having painful paraesthesias of his hands and feet. Identify the poisoning that is characteristically associated with this finding.
questions.solution:
The given images (raindrop pigmentation and Mees lines) along with the clinical features of painful paraesthesias of hands and feet are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. Chelation therapy for subacute or chronic severe arsenic toxicity is succimer (DMSA). It is an oral hydrophilic analogue of BAL.

For acute arsenic toxicity, the following can be used:

  • BAL (British anti-Lewisite)
  • DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) 
  • DMPS (Dimercaptopropane-1-sulfonate) 

BAL tends to remain the initial chelating drug for severe, acute arsenic toxicity. For other cases, DMSA or DMPS may be used. 

The images given below show characteristic raindrop pigmentation and Mees lines, seen in chronic arsenic poisoning.

Note: Arsenic is used industrially as an alloying agent and in the processing of glass, pigments, textiles, paper, metal adhesives, wood preservatives and ammunition. Arsenic is also used in the hide tanning process and, to a limited extent, in pesticides, feed additives, and pharmaceuticals.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy playing at the seashore drowned in the sea during high tide. Which of the following is seen in this type of drowning?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards sea water drowning. Hemoconcentration and hypernatremia is seen in this type of drowning.

Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing hemoconcentration and hypernatremia. This may lead to increased viscosity of blood and in turn lead to myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure and the RBCs get crenated.

Other options: 

Option B: Hemodilution and hyponatremia are seen in freshwater drowning. In freshwater drowning water enters the hypotonic alveoli, which is absorbed to blood easily and will result in hemodilution. This leads to swelling of RBCs, leading to lysis of RBCs causing hyperkalemia. This may lead to ventricular fibrillation and cerebral anoxia within 3-5 minutes and death.

Option A and C: Hemoconcentration with hyponatremia and hemodilution with hypernatremia are not seen in any form of drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following post-mortem changes is a result of hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather?
questions.solution:
Hydrolysis of lipids under warm and humid weather would result in adipocere formation, which is seen in image 4. 

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death. It is seen in cellular death:
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

Adipocere formation (Image 4) is a late sign of death. The transformation is brought about by the gradual hydrolysis and hydrogenation of pre-existing fats, including olein, into higher fatty acids. These higher fatty acids then join with calcium and ammonium ions to produce insoluble soaps, which since they are acidic, prevent putrefactive bacteria. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months. Still, in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 4 to 5 days after death. 

Image 1. Marbling: It is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Image 2. Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Inability to abduct the arm is most likely due to lesion of C5 root.

The deltoid muscle is the main muscle involved in the abduction of the arm. It is innervated by the C5 root of the axillary nerve. So, a lesion involving the C5 causes inability to abduct the arm.

The table below shows the movements and muscles tested to determine the location of the lesion in the upper limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Iris epithelium is not derived from surface ectoderm. It is derived from neural ectoderm.

Lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium are all derivatives of surface ectoderm.

Related Pearl: Embryological derivatives of the eye

Neural Ectoderm

Surface Ectoderm

Mesoderm

Neural Crest

Smooth muscles of iris (sphincter and dilator pupillae)

Iris epithelium 

Crystalline lens

Extraocular muscles 

Corneal stroma, keratocytes, and endothelium

Ciliary epithelium

Corneal epithelium

Superotemporal part of Sclera

Uveal and conjunctival melanocytes

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with fracture forearm and says she has tripped and fell. On examination you notice multiple cigarette burns on her forearm. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
In this case child abuse is suspected. A child who has been physically abused should undergo a thorough physical examination at first to confirm the findings of child abuse to avoid erroneously arriving at conclusions. This should be followed by a psychiatric interview.

When the child is brought to the emergency room, a detailed and spontaneous account of the injury should be obtained promptly from parents or other caregivers before secondary details and rationalizations cloud the information provided.

questions.text: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie requirements in this trimester?
questions.solution:
The pregnant lady can continue the same diet since there are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester.

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal, mostly during the last 20 weeks. To meet this demand, a caloric increase of 100 to 300 kcal/d is recommended during pregnancy. This greater intake, however, should not be divided equally during the course of pregnancy. The Institute of Medicine (2006) recommends adding 0, 340, and 452 kcal/d to the estimated nonpregnant energy requirements in the first, second, and third trimesters respectively. 

Whenever caloric intake is inadequate, protein is metabolized rather than being spared for its vital role in fetal growth and development.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female had 6 attacks of migraine in the last month and was treated for the same. She is not able to tolerate the pain during attacks and came to the hospital asking for medication which can prevent these attacks in the future. The drug which can be used in this patient is ________.
questions.solution:
The drug which can be used in this patient to prevent migraine attack is topiramate.

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in prevention of chronic migraine

Drugs that have not shown benefit in the prophylaxis of migraine: Verapamil, Diltiazem (a calcium channel blocker), nimodipine, clonidine, fluoxetine (an SSRI).

questions.text: An 18-year-old female was sexually assaulted by a 20-year-old male.Barberio's test was performed on the stains and showed yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals.Which of the following is detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test which detects the presence of spermine ,present in prostatic secretions and thus helps in the identification of seminal fluid. 

In Barberio's test, a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid. This produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate.

Option B: Acid phosphatase test is a quantitative test for the presence of acid phosphatase enzyme. High levels of acid phosphatase from prostatic secretions are present in seminal stains (The normal vaginal secretions have low levels of acid phosphatase). Positive reactions are found till 36 hours after which the enzyme levels fall and disappear within 72 hours. In the absence of demonstrable sperms or aspermia, this test can be considered conclusive.

Option C: Florence test detects choline which is secreted by seminal vesicles. The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen.

Option D: Fructose acts as an energy source for sperm. Its presence in seminal fluid indicates a patent efferent ductal system, as fructose will be absent in its obstruction.

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status and rapid, deep breathing. The diagram below illustrates the pattern of respiration observed in the patient. What is the pattern of breathing observed in the diagram, and what is one possible associated cause?
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Kussmaul’s breathing and one of its associated causes includes sepsis. This pattern is often seen in conditions associated with metabolic acidosis.

Kussmaul’s breathing is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually due to metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

Normally, the H+ ions from acids in our body are buffered with various mechanisms. But in cases, where acid production is high like in diabetic ketoacidosis and sepsis, the buffering capacity is exceeded. The resulting acidosis stimulates respiration and decreases alveolar CO2 in order to produce a compensatory fall in the H+ ions.

Other options:

Option A. Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 

Options B: Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing (crescendo-decrescendo cycles), with periods of apnoea. It is seen in patients with heart failure and uremia. This pattern of breathing is associated with increased sensitivity to arterial PCO2 and prolonged lung-to-brain circulation time.

questions.text: In a routine radiographic examination of the ankle joint of a 45-year-old patient, an incidental discovery is observed in the X-ray image as shown below. What is this finding?
questions.solution:
The marked area in the X-ray is Os trigonum which is an accessory bone seen behind the talus.

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon, also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

Other options:

Option C: Fabella is a sesamoid bone. It is found within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral condyle. Radiological mage of fabella is given below.

Option D: Rider's bone is an example of heterotopic calcification involving the Adductor longus muscle.

questions.text: If birth rate is 42 and death rate is 31, then the current annual growth rate is:
questions.solution:
Current annual growth rate = crude birth rate – crude death rate.

In this scenario, Birth rate is 42 i.e 42 live birth per 1000 population  and death rate is 31 i.e 31 death per 1000 population

So, Annual growth rate = 42-31=11 per 1000 population but given options are in percentage (i.e per 100) so option B i.e 1.1 % is the answer

questions.text: You notice that your consultant prescribes a drug called alirocumab for a patient with dyslipidemia. Identify the group this drug belongs to from the following.
questions.solution:
Alirocumab belongs to PCSK-9 inhibitors. It is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK9. 

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy. 

Two approved PCSK-9 inhibitors are alirocumab and evolocumab.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents to the otolaryngology clinic with progressive hearing loss in her right ear. Otoscopy reveals a normal tympanic membrane, and audiometry confirms a diagnosis of otosclerosis. The patient undergoes stapedotomy for the management of her condition. Which of the following is NOT a complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy.

Complications of stapedotomy:

  • SNHL
  • Facial palsy
  • Floating/ submerged footplate
  • Endolymph gusher due to damage to inner ear
  • Dislodgement of piston
  • Post-op vertigo

questions.text:
A young woman is taking regular oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following drugs can be concomitantly used along with OCPs without the need for additional contraceptive measures?

OCPs - Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Omeprazole is an enzyme inhibitor and it does not cause contraceptive failure. Hence, additional contraceptive measures will not be required if there is concomitant use of omeprazole with OCPs.

Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, and Rifampicin are enzyme inducers that increase the degradation of OCPs and decrease their duration of action.

CYP450 enzyme inducers:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Rifampicin
  • Alcohol (chronic)
  • Phenytoin
  • Phenobarbitone

CYP 450 enzyme inhibitors:

  • Sodium valproate
  • SSRIs - fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, sertraline
  • Azole antifungals - ketoconazole, itraconazole, fluconazole
  • Erythromycin, clarithromycin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Omeprazole
  • Grapefruit juice

questions.text: A first-year medical student during his practical exam was given with 1st rib and asked to name the structures related to it. The neck of the 1st rib is related to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The internal thoracic artery is not related to the neck of the first rib.

The structures related to neck of the first rib (medial to lateral):

  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein ( posterior intercostal)
  • Artery (superior intercostal)
  • Nerve (T1 nerve)

These structures are also related to the apex of lung anteriorly.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of persistent hoarseness of voice for the past six months. He reports no significant history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption. Upon further examination, a suspicious lesion is noted on laryngoscopy, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following does not contribute to the development of hoarseness of voice in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Phonotrauma is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal carcinoma. It occurs due to overuse of voice and is associated with the development of benign lesions such as vocal nodules and cysts.

Hoarseness in supraglottic cancer and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to:

  • Vocal cords with infiltration of the thyroarytenoid muscle
  • Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • Cricoarytenoid joint involvement.

Hoarseness in glottic carcinoma is early because lesions of the cord affect its vibratory capacity.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is found only in the mitochondria and helps in the mitochondrial function ?
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin is the phospholipid found only in the mitochondria. 

It is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it is essential for the following:

  • Optimal function of numerous mitochondrial enzymes that are involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Maintenance of the structure of the mitochondrial membrane.

Clinical correlate:

Decreased cardiolipin or alteration in its metabolism results in mitochondrial dysfunction seen in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy) which is characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy ), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured during an emergency mid-line tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
The structure that is not damaged during an emergency tracheostomy is the inferior thyroid artery, as it is not a mid-line structure. Inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk of the subclavian artery.

Isthumus, arteria thyroid ima, inferior thyroid vein are in the midline and are prone to damage during tracheostomy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with firm papules with a rough surface on the genitalia. Histopathology of the tissues from the lesion is shown below. These findings are seen in _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing koilocytes are seen in papillomavirus infection.

Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear cavitation, nuclear enlargement, coarse chromatin, and irregular nuclear membranes. A rim of condensed cytoplasm around the perinuclear cavitation gives the cell a halo or cleared-out appearance. Koilocytes are often seen in cervical cancer, premalignant lesions of the cervix, genital warts, and anal and oral cancers. 

Genital warts or condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths caused by human papillomavirus, that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or merge to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. 

The following image shows pap staining showing koilocytes.

Other options:

Option A: Polyomavirus infections are associated with the presence of decoy cells in histopathology. Decoy cells are epithelial cells with intranuclear viral inclusion bodies characterized by large, homogenous, amorphous ground-glass-like intranuclear inclusion bodies and a condensed rim of chromatin.

Option C: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection that appears as discrete, pearly, umbilicated papules. It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale infection usually presents as genital ulcers. It is characterized by large mononuclear cells, whose cytoplasm contains numerous organisms that show bipolar staining with a safety‐pin appearance, called Donovan bodies.

questions.text: After synthesis, eukaryotic mRNA undergoes extensive modifications including which of the following?
questions.solution:
After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly A tail and splicing

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backward to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. These tails help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation.
  • Maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns & joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. The process of removing introns and joining exons is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

questions.text: The area marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The area marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest. Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branched filaments like a 'Spaghetti and meatball appearance'. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of  Pityriasis Versicolor and the causative agent is the lipophilic, yeast-like fungus Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporum orbiculare).

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic, usually asymptomatic, involvement of the stratum corneum, characterized by discrete or confluent macular areas of discoloration or de-pigmentation of the skin.

The areas involved are mainly the chest, abdomen, upper limbs, and back.

Skin scraping and KOH preparation show an abundance of yeast-like cells and short branched filaments (Spaghetti and meatball appearance).

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolour over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

Other options:

  • Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 
  • Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in the Marshall's triad for blast injuries?
questions.solution:
Fracture is not included in the Marshall's triad for blast injuries.

Marshall’s triad is associated with blast injuries. The triad includes:

  • Bruises
  • Abrasions
  • Puncture lacerations

questions.text: Which of the following is best described by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts smothering. It refers to the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric.

  • Burking: a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing the chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands.
  • Throttling/manual strangulation: defined as compression and strangulation with bare hands.
     
  • Choking: blockage of the upper airways by some foreign body, but is also used for manual strangulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker for apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Annexin V is the marker of Apoptosis.

Other options:

Option A: Annexin A1 is the marker for Hairy cell leukaemia.

Option B: CD117 is the marker for Gastrointestinal stromal tumours.

Option C: CD99 the marker for Ewing sarcoma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a recent altercation where he sustained a blow to his nose. He complains of difficulty breathing through his nose and increasing pain and pressure in the nasal region. On examination, bilateral nasal obstruction is noted, along with tenderness and swelling of the nasal septum. Which of the following is not true in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms and the history of trauma are most likely indicative of a septal hematoma and it is treated with aspiration or incision and drainage.

Septal Haematoma:

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: A patient who presents to the OPD has a visual field defect as shown below. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma marked as 3 in the image given. 

Options marked in the image are:

1. Left optic nerve 
3. Otic chiasma
4. Left optic tract 
5. Left lateral geniculate nucleus

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not show vertical transmission?
questions.solution:
Tetanus does not show vertical or transplacental transmission.

Transmission of diseases or non-infectious agents transplacentally is called vertical transmission. Diseases that show this type of transmission include:

  • Herpes
  • HIV
  • Rubella
  • Varicella

Apart from diseases, non-infectious agents like lithium, thalidomide, stilbestrol, etc. can cross the placenta and lead to the development of congenital anomalies in a foetus.

Note: Neonatal tetanus occurs as a result of the failure to use aseptic techniques in managing the umbilical stump, unclean hands, and instruments or contamination by dirt, straw, or other nonsterile materials in the delivery field. Immunisation of pregnant women can prevent this disease via the transplacental transport of immunoglobulins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and is prescribed insulin therapy to manage blood glucose levels. The physician explains to the patient the mechanism by which insulin facilitates glucose entry into the cells. Which of the following terms best describes this process of travel of these cells?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to a lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion. 

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Glucose transporters also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions inside the cell membrane by binding to a carrier/ transport protein. 

For example, insulin stimulates glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane. This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues. 

Other options - 

Option A. Simple diffusion - It is along the concentration gradient but is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Option C. Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against a membrane with chemical or electrical gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option D. In secondary active transport, the active transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances. Examples include symport of sodium with glucose (luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine), sodium-potassium ATPase, and Ca2+ in the cardiac muscle cells.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text: A physiologist is experimenting to determine the tetanizing frequency of a muscle. The latent period of the muscle twitch is measured to be 10 milliseconds (ms), and the contraction period is 40 ms. What is the tetanizing frequency in Hertz (Hz)?
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/40 ms = 25 Hz.

Tetanizing frequency

  • As the contractile mechanism does not have a refractory period, on rapid stimulation of a muscle, each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, and thus the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. Such a response is called a tetanus (tetanic contraction). It is a complete tetanus when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Tetany occurs because enough calcium ions are maintained in the muscle sarcoplasm throughout stimulation.

questions.text: At PHCs, vaccines are stored in:
questions.solution:
Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centres (PHCs).

ILRs are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 degree Celsius for storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs. Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ILR.

Inside the ILR there is a lining of water containers (ice packs or tubes) fitted all around the walls. When the refrigerator is functioning the water in the containers freezes and cools the cabinet. When the electricity supply fails, then the ice lining maintains the inside temperature of the refrigerator at a safe level for vaccines. Therefore, the temperature is maintained in ILR for a much longer duration than in the deep freezers and domestic refrigerators. Thus ILR is an ideal option for safe storage of vaccines.

Related Pearl: Cold Chain Equipment

Cold chain equipment : 

Storage : 

  • Walk in cooler (WIC)
  • Walk in freezer (WIF)
  • Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  • Deep freezer 
  • Domestic refrigerator

  • Solar Refrigerator Direct drive

  • Cold box

  • Refrigerator vaccine van
  • Insulated vaccine van

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and chronic diarrhea for 4 months. Endoscopy reveals several ulcers in the gastric antrum and the descending duodenum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gastrinoma- Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors. In 75% of patients, gastrinomas are sporadic, solitary lesions. The remaining 25% of patients with gastrinomas have multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). Gastrinomas usually arise in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Patients present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. Ulcers may occur in unusual locations such as the jejunum; when intractable jejunal ulcers are found, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome should be considered. 

Treatment of individuals with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome includes blockade of acid hypersecretion, typically with proton pump inhibitors. 

Other options:

Option A: VIPoma is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). It is caused by the release of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the tumor.

Option C: Glucagonomas, α-cell tumors are associated with increased serum levels of glucagon. The patient presents with mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia. They occur most frequently in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women and are characterized by extremely high plasma glucagon levels.

Option D: Insulinomas, β-cell tumors are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50 mg/dL. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

 

Related Pearl: Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

  • Unregulated gastrin release from a non β cell endocrine tumor (gastrinoma)
  • Gastrinomas may be sporadic (M/C) or may be associated with MEN 1 syndrome
  • Females are more commonly affected, between 30-50 years
  • Long-standing hypergastrinemia leads to hyperchlorhydria
  • Peptic ulcer is the most common clinical manifestation
  • Clinical situations that should create suspicion of gastrinoma:
    • Ulcers in unusual locations (second part of the duodenum and beyond)
    • Refractory ulcers
    • Postoperative ulcer recurrence
    • Ulcers presenting with frank complications
    • Ulcers in the absence of H. pylori or NSAID ingestion
  • Diarrhoea is seen in 50% patients
  • The first step in evaluation is to obtain a fasting gastrin level
  • A BAO >15meq/h in the presence of hypergastrinemia is considered pathognomonic of ZES
  • BAO/MAO > 0.6 (BAO = basal acid output) (MAO=maximal acid output)
  • PPIs are the treatment of choice

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding after the removal of an IV cannula. He underwent a small bowel resection and was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital stay. His lab investigations show an elevated prothrombin time (PT). The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin K is responsible for this condition.

Vitamin K deficiency in adults may be seen in patients with chronic small-intestinal diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s disease, obstructed biliary tracts, and after small-bowel resection. Additionally, broad-spectrum antibiotics can precipitate Vitamin K deficiency by reducing the number of gut bacteria, which synthesize menaquinones.

It is a fat-soluble vitamin that has two natural forms: Vitamin K1, also known as phylloquinone, from vegetable sources, and vitamin K2, or menaquinones, which are synthesized by bacterial flora and found in hepatic tissue.

Vitamin K is required for the posttranslational carboxylation of glutamic acid, which is necessary for calcium binding to γ-carboxylated proteins such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factors VII, IX, and X
  • protein C, protein S

Patients with vitamin K deficiency usually present with a history of bleeding either at venipuncture sites or minor trauma.

It is diagnosed on the basis of an elevated prothrombin time or reduced clotting factors. It is treated with supplementation by oral or IV route.

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Option B: Vitamin E deficiency manifests as peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy. Usually seen with fat malabsorption or genetic abnormalities of vitamin E metabolism.

Option C: Niacin deficiency manifests as pellagra, which includes symptoms of diarrhea, a pigmented rash over sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, memory loss, and altered sensorium. Alcoholism, vitamin B6 deficiency, riboflavin, and tryptophan deficiencies predispose to this condition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

The biopsy image shows tumor cells with multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and high mitotic index closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (the "sky"). These cells have a high turnover rate. The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris which are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris ( the "stars"). This produces a starry sky appearance, which is classical of Burkitt lymphoma. 

Burkitt lymphoma:

  • Most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Associated with translocation of MYC gene of chromosome 8 (Option A)
  • Translocations: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated (Option B)
    • Sporadic: in adults in western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67)

Histology: Starry sky pattern

Immunophenotype: 

  • The tumor cells express
    • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
    • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
    • Germinal center-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
    • HLA-DR and CD43.
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors.
    • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression

Note: Although in most cases BCL2 is negative, it can be positive. The expression of BCL2 does not exclude a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Hence, this is the most appropriate answer in the MCQ.

Treatment: Begins within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with the use of an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.

questions.text: Program for improvement of quality of labor room comes under:
questions.solution:
The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the government of India refers to initiative for labor room quality improvement.

There is enough evidence to show that improving the quality of care in labor rooms, especially on the day of birth, is central to maternal and neonatal survival.

  • Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care that is being provided to the pregnant mother in the labor room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth.
  • This initiative will be implemented in government medical colleges (MCs) besides district hospitals (DHs), and high delivery load sub-district hospitals (SDHs) and community health centers (CHCs).
  • The initiative plans to conduct quality certification of labor rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving the targets outlined.
  • The goal of this initiative is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in the labor room and maternity OT and ensure respectful maternity care.

questions.text: The following is not a vestibular sedative
questions.solution:
Carbogen is a mixture of 5%CO2 and 95% O2. It is a cerebral vasodilator and not vestibular sedative.

The first line of treatment of an acute episode of Meniere’s is symptomatic and hence vestibular sedatives are the mainstay in the treatment. These are

  • Dimenhydrinate-anti-histaminic agent.
  • Prochlorperazine
  • Promethazine
